item.description:
Contact

To avoid spam, please contact me using my personal contact form at Drupal.org, or on LinkedIn, or Github. If you aren't sure, then create an account on Drupal.org, as it is a reputable community driven site that I trust to keep our communication private and safe.

item.title: Purple Claro Drupal Theme
item.description:
Purple Claro Drupal Theme

I made a simple sub-theme of Claro that I use for this site called Purple Claro. The only difference is it adds some shades of purple to it. When I'm doing contrib work, I end up seeing the grey Claro theme from core but I miss my Purple Claro. So, I planned to publish my purple theme so it's easy to pull it in with composer when I'm doing other work.

My first thought was to make a sub-theme of Claro. I tried that. But it turns out that when you just try to make a simple sub-theme using the instructions on Drupal.org, there are things that still didn't work right. I had to manually export config for block layout, for starters. Then, I noticed that the nice little star icon next to page titles to add a shortcut was missing. So, I looked into how that was added but it turns out that the shortcut module and the Claro theme are dependent on each other for that functionality making it so I can't just reuse it. There seem to be a lot of modifications like this in Claro that I would have to figure out workarounds for.

So, my next thought is to make a module that just injects some CSS into Claro instead of making a sub-theme. We'll see how that goes...

OK, it's the next day. The dev version of the new Purple Claro module is on Drupal.org :) 

brooke Sun, 21 Sep 2025 - 10:57
Tags
Drupal
item.dc:creator: brooke

item.title: Step Debugging Drupal Contributed Projects with DDEV and Xdebug
item.description:
Step Debugging Drupal Contributed Projects with DDEV and Xdebug

Yesterday I step debugged on Drupal 9, 10, and 11 while working on the Easy Breadcrumb module. It was a bit nerve-wracking at times to set up, but it all works great now.

To be able to set it up, I used a combination of:

  • The documentation and functionality of the DDEV contrib add-on
  • The DDEV docs on setting up Xdebug with VSCodium
  • Perseverance

I'm really happy using DDEV. It helps to make contributing back to the Drupal community much easier than it used to be.

item.title: Today was Dependency Injection Day
item.description:
Today was Dependency Injection Day

The Config Suite module had some warnings from PHP Code Sniffer and PHPStan. I created some issues for that and ended up making three merge requests to get it all up to date. Much of my time was spent updating the old code to use dependency injection... define arguments in services.yml, add the services to the class in the constructor with annotations, repeat yourself and document all the new class variables like was done in the constructor.

https://www.drupal.org/project/config_suite/issues/3547548

https://www.drupal.org/project/config_suite/issues/3547547

https://www.drupal.org/project/config_suite/issues/3547542

item.title: Running Tests Locally for Drupal Contributed Modules
item.description:
Running Tests Locally for Drupal Contributed Modules

Let's take a look at the Easy Breadcrumb module's issue queue. This looks like an interesting one: 10.4+: Cache issue (BreadcrumbBuilderInterface::applies() now takes a second $cacheable_metadata argument) . It involves failing tests. I'll use the ddev addon for drupal contrib.

When using that addon, I can easily run tests, like PHPUnit and PHP Code Sniffer (PHPcs). One of the issues that Easy Breadcrumb has is that it's failing PHPcs tests. I want to make changes but ignore all the stuff that was added by .ddev and drupal core when I look at the git diff. So, I add a .gitignore to the root folder with these contents:

.ddev
vendor
web
recipes
.editorconfig
.gitattributes
.gitignore
phpcs.xml.dist
phpstan.neon
phpstan-baseline.neon

Alright, added a merge request for that one. It took awhile to understand what the correct code fix was. It was nice to be able to use VS Code and the Drupal extension to be able to navigate Drupal Core code so intuitively.

OK, added another merge request, this time for Address PHPCS errors in gitlab-ci jobs. I really like the new Gitlab workflow for Drupal Contrib.

brooke Wed, 17 Sep 2025 - 20:31

item.title: Drupal 11 CKEditor5 Code Highlighting
item.description:
Drupal 11 CKEditor5 Code Highlighting

Well, I guess bash isn't the most common of things to highlight or something because CKEditor5 in Drupal 11 doesn't come with that function. So, now I have to go figure out the best way to do the highlighting. First, I wonder if there is highlighting on any of the code block choices? Let's try some PHP:

<?php

function hook_ckeditor5_plugin_info_alter(array &$plugin_definitions): void {}

OK, well, that didn't work (well, it works now, but it didn't when I wrote that). It comes out as plain text. OK, let's see which modules are best for syntax highlighting nowadays. From what I see, CKEditor and highlight.js are a common pair. I'll do that. I'll try out the Highlight Js syntax highlighter module .

That did it :)

brooke Wed, 17 Sep 2025 - 16:56

item.title: Bash scripts for Drupal, DDEV, and Tome
item.description:
Bash scripts for Drupal, DDEV, and Tome

Well, I got the website all working with Drupal. I have Tome successfully exporting the dynamic site to a static site. I'm using some custom bash code to build and preview the static site. It use Concurrently to run two processes in one terminal session.

alias brookemahoneycomCd='cd ~/Sites/brookemahoneycom'
brookemahoneycomLaunch () {
  brookemahoneycomCd
  cd drupal
  ddev launch
}
brookemahoneycomPreview () {
  brookemahoneycomCd
  cd docs
  concurrently 'python -m http.server' 'open "http://localhost:8000"'
}

brookemahoneycomBuild() {
  # Starts Orbstack if it isn't running.
  orb
  # Changes to the drupal directory.
  cd ~/Sites/brookemahoneycom/drupal
  # Exports the site with Tome.
  ddev drush tome:static --uri=https://brookemahoney.com
  # Removes old docs directory.
  rm -rf ~/Sites/brookemahoneycom/docs
  # Copies the Tome build directory to docs for Github hosting.
  cp -R ~/Sites/brookemahoneycom/drupal/html ~/Sites/brookemahoneycom/docs
  # Copies CNAME file for Github hosting.
  cp ~/projects/brookemahoneycom/sync/CNAME ~/Sites/brookemahoneycom/docs/CNAME
}

All the code for the Drupal install is in this site's Github repo.

I also added the Menu Link Attributes and Easy Breadcrumb modules.

brooke Wed, 17 Sep 2025 - 13:46
Tags
Drupal

item.title: Evaluating Drupal CMS
item.description:
Evaluating Drupal CMS

Here we go

Yesterday was a busy day, for sure. I learned so much. I learned the new workflows of Drupal core and contrib development. I contributed to DDEV's documentation. I found in issue in Drupal CMS, created a fix, and made my first Gitlab merge request.

Speaking of DDEV, I'm watching, Contributor Training: Using Claude Code for DDEV Development", from the DDEV team on YouTube.

Old Distributions remind me of Drupal CMS

Years ago, I used to tell people that Drupal distributions should be used as examples for building sites instead of using them as a starting code base and extending them. Drupal distributions were great but sometimes they caused headaches when you wanted to override their functions. This is how I feel about Drupal CMS, so far. I will use it as an example and I'll build my own site with Drupal Core as a starting point. I'll be taking a look at each of the core and contributed modules that ship with Drupal CMS, taking note of which ones I'll need for the blog.

Modules I'll start with

Pathauto and Redirect should do. I'll disable all the modules that don't make sense for a static site.

Theming

For a theme, I'll use the guide on Drupal.org, https://www.drupal.org/docs/develop/theming-drupal/creating-sub-themes, and use the option to generate a theme using drush:

ddev drush generate theme

 

brooke Sun, 14 Sep 2025 - 16:51
